August 24, 2008: Fiction
ACHERON, by Sherrilyn Kenyon. (St. Martin’s, $24.95.) Book 12 of the Dark-
Hunter paranormal series.
THE BOURNE SANCTION, by Eric Van Lustbader. (Grand Central, $25.99.)
Robert Ludlum’s character Jason Bourne pursues the leader of a Muslim terrorist
group.
THE GUERNSEY LITERARY AND POTATO PEEL PIE SOCIETY, by Mary Ann
Shaffer and Annie Barrows. (Dial, $22.) After World War II, a journalist travels to
the island of Guernsey to meet residents who resisted the Nazi occupation.
MOSCOW RULES, by Daniel Silva. (Putnam, $26.95.) Gabriel Allon, an art
restorer and an occasional spy for the Israeli secret service, uncovers a Russian
arms sales plot.
THE HOST, by Stephenie Meyer. (Little, Brown, $25.99.) Aliens have taken
control of the minds and bodies of most humans, but one woman won’t surrender.
THE STORY OF EDGAR SAWTELLE, by David Wroblewski. (Ecco, $25.95.) A
mute takes refuge with three dogs in the Wisconsin woods after his father’s
murder.
THE LACE READER, by Brunonia Barry. (Morrow, $24.95.) Secrets of a family of
Salem women who foresee the future.
TRIBUTE, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam, $26.95.) A former child star returns to
Virginia to rehabilitate the farm owned by her grandmother, an actress who died
mysteriously.
FOREIGN BODY, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $25.95.) A medical student
investigates a rising number of deaths among medical tourists at foreign hospitals.
THE LAST PATRIOT, by Brad Thor. (Atria, $26.) Scot Harvath, a Homeland
Security superagent, searches for an ancient secret that could defeat Islamic
militants.
CHASING HARRY WINSTON, by Lauren Weisberger. (Simon & Schuster,
$25.95.) Three glamorous friends, New York women nearing 30, vow to change
their lives.
THE ASSASSIN, by Stephen Coonts. (St. Martin’s) A top Qaeda terrorist pursues
the Western leaders who are trying to defeat him.
LOVE THE ONE YOU’RE WITH, by Emily Giffin. (St. Martin’s, $24.95.) A woman
encounters an old boyfriend.
THE GARGOYLE, by Andrew Davidson. (Doubleday, $25.95.) A hideously burned
August 24, 2008
Non-Fiction
THE OBAMA NATION, by Jerome R. Corsi. (Threshold, $28.) The Democratic
candidate as an extreme leftist, from a co-author of “Unfit for Command: Swift
Boat Veterans Speak Out Against John Kerry.”
STORI TELLING, by Tori Spelling with Hilary Liftin. (Simon Spotlight
Entertainment, $24.95.) A memoir.
THE WAY OF THE WORLD, by Ron Suskind. (Harper, 27.95.) How the Bush
administration ignored evidence about Iraq in its rush to war.
WHEN YOU ARE ENGULFED IN FLAMES, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown,
$25.99.) The humorist’s latest essays.
THE CASE AGAINST BARACK OBAMA, by David Freddoso. (Regnery, $27.95.)
The Democratic candidate as a calculating extreme leftist.
ARE YOU THERE, VODKA? IT’S ME, CHELSEA, by Chelsea Handler. (Simon
Spotlight Entertainment, $24.95.) Humorous personal essays from the stand-up
comedian.
THE DARK SIDE, by Jane Mayer. (Doubleday, $27.50.) How the Bush
administration embraced the practice of torture.
FLEECED, by Dick Morris and Eileen McGann. (Harper, $26.95.) Americans are
fleeced by government, business, labor unions and lobbyists.
LIFE WITH MY SISTER MADONNA, by Christopher Ciccone with Wendy Leigh.
(Simon Spotlight Entertainment, $26.) What she’s really like.
THE PROSECUTION OF GEORGE W. BUSH FOR MURDER, by Vincent
Bugliosi. (Vanguard, $26.95.) The Manson prosecutor makes a case for trying the
president for the deaths of 4,000 American soldiers in Iraq.
THE WRECKING CREW, by Thomas Frank. (Metropolitan/Holt, $25.) The
deliberate mismanagement of Republican rule.
THE POST-AMERICAN WORLD, by Fareed Zakaria. (Norton, $25.95.) The rise of
China and India.
HAVANA NOCTURNE, by T. J. English. (Morrow, $27.95.) When American
gangsters controlled Cuba’s casinos.
WAITER RANT, by the Waiter. (Ecco, $24.95.) An anonymous New York waiter
on customers’ outrageous behavior.
THE MONSTER OF FLORENCE, by Douglas Preston with Mario Spezi. (Grand
